stream_context.summary: Kaze finishes an underground oil-rig section by modeling N64-style drill props, implementing a new oil-based enemy (Fizz Oil) with animation and behavior, and prototyping a “slippery floor” mechanic without touching engine code. He also gives status updates on Course 4/zoo repairs and beta readiness, discusses optimization/engine constraints, and briefly touches on ROMhack legal realities (patches, IP enforcement, a creator hiring an IP lawyer).
stream_context.significance_reason: The stream completes a distinct area’s content pass (visuals + new enemy + new surface/slippery mechanic) and includes concrete engine/optimization philosophy plus production status (Course 4 ready for beta; zoo waiting on Zeina animations).

findings.summary: Kaze considers the current underground oil-rig area essentially finished after adding the drill props and implementing the missing enemy; remaining polish items are oil clouds, dead fish set dressing, and a boiling-oil environmental effect.

He designs a new enemy, “Fizz Oil” (inspired by SMG’s Fizz Lit), that crawls, then “swoops” into a puddle state; the intended gameplay value is environmental hazard/pressure (sliding on stairs into boiling oil) rather than direct damage.

To make Fizz Oil affect gameplay without engine edits, he dynamically modifies the surface type of the triangle under Mario while Mario is within the enemy’s radius, then resets it—creating localized slipperiness as a per-frame external behavior.
findings.quote: Since we don’t want to touch engine code, we need to somehow externally do this.

findings.summary: He decides Fizz Oil should be killable with “soap” as a teaching/hint mechanism for a related boss concept, but avoids making it star-rewarding; solution is to have it drop small rewards (e.g., coins) instead of counting as a star objective.

He runs into a bug where the enemy’s texture/eye animation argument wasn’t applying because the relevant function/action routing wasn’t running as expected; diagnosing reveals an action incorrectly transitioning (action 4 going to action 0 instead of action 5), which explains broken animation behavior.

Kaze notes a planned performance improvement: transposing the scale-table matrix because the current layout is “terrible for cache cleaning,” reflecting his ongoing low-level optimization approach during feature work.

He highlights that switching to hashing tables (instead of normal geo layouts) dramatically increases available geo/model space—allowing model IDs up to 0x60—making larger/more varied scene geometry feasible.
findings.quote: It’s so freeing that we have hashing tables now instead of normal geo layouts, because now we have so much more space for geos.

findings.summary: Fast64 has a rendering bug that makes the area look worse in Blender; he treats it as a tooling limitation and proceeds, noting Fast64 is open source but he wishes more people were working on it.

Off-stream, he finished fixing Course 4 and says it’s ready to be sent for beta testing; he also says working on new content tends to break older levels, so he’s doing a sweep of old courses for repairs and bug fixes.

The zoo course is repaired and functional again, but is blocked on a few animations Zeina is making; Kaze is also thinking through how a zoo star-select/travel sequence should work without breaking the game’s star-select “Mario travels to the level” concept.

Kaze frames ROMhack distribution as effectively a full-game replacement despite being delivered as a “patch,” and he discusses Nintendo enforcement as driven by IP-protection obligations; he also mentions a ROMhacker who hired an IP lawyer to contest a takedown and may get a YouTube video reinstated.

He says making a brand-new N64 game (separate from RTY’s engine/hack work) isn’t financially viable for him, especially because he now has a family to provide for, forcing more pragmatic project choices.
findings.quote: I do have a family now that I need to provide for, so I can’t just fuck around with my time and do that.

findings.summary: Kaze explicitly commits to open-sourcing the codebase so it can be maintained after he leaves the scene and so others can build hacks on top of his engine work.
findings.quote: This is guaranteed open source. I want people to be able to maintain this code base after I leave the scene, and I want other people to be able to make hacks off of my engine.

biobak.summary: Biobak is present in chat; Kaze anticipates Biobak’s typical feedback style (notably color balance critique and polygon/triangle budget policing), and Kaze removes extra triangles preemptively to avoid being called out.

badub.summary: Kaze reacts positively to the stream’s background music (“really nice”), implying continued iteration/review of in-game tracks during development even though no specific track decisions are finalized here.

zeina.summary: Zeina is producing animations needed to restore/finish the zoo course; the course’s readiness is dependent on her animation deliveries.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: This is guaranteed open source. I want people to be able to maintain this code base after I leave the scene, and I want other people to be able to make hacks off of my engine.
memorable_quotes.context: A clear statement of legacy intent: RTY isn’t just a game, it’s an engine/codebase meant to outlive him and empower other creators.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: I do have a family now that I need to provide for, so I can’t just fuck around with my time and do that. I have to make sensible decisions.
memorable_quotes.context: Explains why he prioritizes RTY/engine work over riskier passion projects (like a totally new N64 game), grounding creative choices in real-life constraints.

key_stories.title: Building an enemy that changes physics without changing the engine
key_stories.summary: Kaze wants an oil enemy that makes traversal harder by making surfaces slippery, but he tries to avoid modifying core engine code. He prototypes a solution where the enemy behavior temporarily edits the surface type of the floor triangle under Mario whenever Mario is within a radius, then resets it.
key_stories.challenge: Create a distinctive hazard (slipperiness) while minimizing engine edits and performance costs.
key_stories.process: He reasons through multiple options (engine-level flags vs external behavior), selects dynamic surface edits, adds backup state (surface pointer/type) and resets per frame for reliability, and tests the result on stair-heavy terrain where slipping matters.
key_stories.outcome: The localized slipperiness works and becomes the signature mechanic of Fizz Oil; remaining follow-up is integrating soap-kill behavior cleanly and polishing the area (boiling oil, set dressing).
key_stories.key_quote: Since we don’t want to touch engine code, we need to somehow externally do this.

key_stories.title: Course 4 and the cascade of breakage from new development
key_stories.summary: Kaze reports finishing off-stream repairs to Course 4 and preparing it for beta testing, while also noting that ongoing work regularly breaks older levels. He’s doing broad regression-style passes to restore functionality across previously completed content.
key_stories.challenge: Maintaining stability across many courses while adding new systems and assets.
key_stories.process: He revisits older levels, fixes bugs discovered during testing, and coordinates pending art/animation dependencies (notably Zeina’s zoo animations).
key_stories.outcome: Course 4 is declared ready for beta; the zoo course is mostly repaired but waiting on animations.

key_stories.title: Legal posture: patches, IP enforcement, and testing a lawyer route
key_stories.summary: Kaze discusses that although hacks are distributed as patches, RTY effectively replaces almost all bytes of the original ROM. He explains Nintendo’s likely reasoning as IP-protection obligation rather than pure lost sales and mentions a separate ROMhacker hiring an IP lawyer to contest a YouTube takedown.
key_stories.challenge: Operating in a space where Nintendo enforcement can remove content and distribution is legally fragile.
key_stories.process: He describes the practical strategy of releasing as a patch and paying attention to emerging precedents (like lawyer-mediated disputes).
key_stories.outcome: No immediate action taken on stream, but it informs how the project frames distribution and risk; Kaze considers sharing the lawyer-success screenshot publicly.

open_questions.topic: Fizz Oil’s final design and player learning goal
open_questions.context: Fizz Oil currently focuses on vibe + traversal pressure via temporary slipperiness; Kaze debates whether it should also deal damage (e.g., boiling state) and settles on soap-kill as a hint mechanic, with coin drops to avoid star reward expectations.
questions: What boss or later challenge is the soap-kill mechanic meant to foreshadow, and how intentionally is RTY teaching mechanics through enemies like Fizz Oil?
Did playtesting show slipperiness alone was readable/fun, or did players need additional feedback (sound, particles, animation) to understand why movement changed?
How did you decide on ‘vibes over lethality’ here—was that a broader RTY philosophy to keep some enemies as atmosphere rather than hard obstacles?

open_questions.context: Kaze notes the bottom of the area should be boiling oil and mentions needing black bubbles, but hasn’t designed the effect yet; later he experiments with particle systems and notes some presets read like “soul leaving the body.”
questions: What final visual language did you choose for boiling oil so players read it as dangerous (not water, not lava), and what constraints did N64 particle/rendering put on that choice?
Did you implement boiling oil as a surface type, an object volume, a particle/visual-only layer, or a combination?
How do you ensure hazards remain readable in foggy/blue-heavy lighting without overusing contrast or modern effects?

open_questions.topic: Star select ‘Mario travels to the level’ concept vs special courses (zoo)
open_questions.context: Kaze says star select is meant to show Mario traveling to the level, and worries a zoo-specific star select might break that conceptual framing; he’s considering a zoo star-select solution.
questions: What is the exact ‘Mario travels to the level’ rule for RTY’s star select, and why was it important to you compared to a standard menu?
How did you resolve exceptions like the zoo—did you redesign the star select, the course framing, or the fiction of how Mario enters it?
Were there other levels where this star-select travel concept constrained level theming or layout decisions?

open_questions.topic: Engine/optimization philosophy: avoiding engine edits and micro-optimizing cache behavior
open_questions.context: Kaze avoids an engine-level ‘treat surfaces slippery’ variable because it would add cache access and be ‘bad practice,’ and he flags a future performance tweak (transpose scale-table matrix) for better cache behavior.
questions: How often did you choose a more complex gameplay workaround specifically to avoid engine edits, and what were the biggest wins/losses of that philosophy?
Can you quantify the performance headroom you’re targeting on real hardware (frame time budgets, object counts, worst-case scenes)?
What were the major engine-level changes you *did* allow, and what criteria made them worth the cost compared to per-object hacks like the Fizz Oil surface edit?

open_questions.context: Kaze promises the project will be open source so others can maintain it after he leaves the scene and so people can build hacks off his engine.
questions: When did you decide RTY would be open source, and was it motivated by past experiences with abandoned hacks/tools?
What parts will be most reusable as an ‘engine’ for others (movement, rendering extensions, tools, build pipeline), and what parts are too RTY-specific?
How do you plan governance/maintenance—will there be trusted maintainers, documentation standards, or a roadmap for external contributors?
